qas.question: What animal has shown extreme inventiveness in the clothing it has devised?
What are space suits an example of a solution to?
What type of implication might a certain type of clothing have?
What value may clothing designed to be fashionable also have?
Why are some parts of the body covered?
Humans have shown little inventiveness in what?
What does not have social implications

plausible_answers.text: They cover parts of the body

qas.question: What do social norms not require of clothes?
The distinction between clothing and what is always clear?
Clothing that is designed to be fashionable is not also what

context: <a0_0>Humans<a0_0/> have shown extreme inventiveness in devising <b5_0>clothing solutions to <a1_0>environmental hazards<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Examples include: space suits, air conditioned clothing, armor, diving suits, swimsuits, bee-keeper gear, motorcycle leathers, high-visibility clothing, and other pieces of protective clothing. Meanwhile, the distinction between clothing and <b8_0>protective equipment<b8_0/> is not always clear-cut—since clothes designed to be fashionable often have <a3_0><b9_0>protective<b9_0/><a3_0/> value and clothes designed for function often consider fashion in their design. <b6_0>Wearing clothes<b6_0/> also has <a2_0>social<a2_0/> implications. <b7_0>They cover parts of the body<b7_0/> that <a4_0>social norms<a4_0/> require to be covered, act as a form of adornment, and serve other social purposes.
